journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Investigation of the nonlinear behaviour of damping of aluminum foam core sandwich composite beams

article-meta.aff: 1Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Semnan University, Semnan, Iran
2Young Researchers Club, Ardabil Branch, Islamic Azad University, Ardabil, Iran

author-notes.corresp: A Hazrati Niyari, Young Researchers Club, Ardabil Branch, Islamic Azad University, Ardabil, Iran Email: a.hazratii@yahoo.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Damping is a useful parameter for controlling vibration and movement in the design of the structure. In many structural applications, damping provides sufficient energy dissipation by suppressing resonant amplitudes of vibration. The present paper is concerned with the utilization of the finite element-based modal strain energy method for predicting the modal loss factor of laminated composite beams. Finite element analysis is performed to study the effects of layerwise in-plane displacements on speciﬁc damping capacity for Duocel aluminum foam core sandwich composite beams. The core was sandwiched between two face sheet graphite/epoxy laminates with a constant thickness. A numerical modelling of the damping response in axisymmetrical conditions was performed using the ABAQUS commercial software. All calculations about the theoretical approach were performed using the MATLAB Version 7.8 (Mathworks Inc.). A good match between the ﬁnite element modelling and the theoretical approach was obtained.

kwd-group.kwd: duocel aluminum foam core sandwich composite

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In aerospace and many other lightweight structures, there are many vibration inputs that can lead to resonance. It is necessary to have a sound methodology to be able to predict naturalfrequencies, it is necessary to understand the damping mechanism in the structure, especially the contribution to passive damping in the structural material. Composite materials generally have a higher damping capacity than metals. The initial works on the damping analysis of ﬁbre composite materials were reviewed extensively in review papers by Puente, Zaera, Navarro.1 Bicos and Springer2 explored the dynamic response of shell structures using the damped element model in a finite element method (FEM) analysis.3–5 The potential applications of aluminum foams have been envisaged in the area of automotive industries, light weight construction materials, silencers, flame arrester, heaters and heat exchangers, catalysts, electrochemical applications, military armour vehicles and aircraft industries. We also know that foams in the transport industry are basically needed for weight saving, impact absorbing and thermal insulation.6–9 Materials with internal interfaces, as indicated by the interfaces of the lamina of conventional composite materials, can dissipate mechanical energy through the movement of the interface by mechanism such as a discontinuity of stress across the interface or by friction losses.10 Although it is difficult to analyse the individual mechanism for a specific material, from the view point of mechanics, a general method for damping prediction can be extended analytically by considering the in-plane stresses as well as the transverse shear stress. Due to the plastic compressibility of foams, we decided to model the damping behaviour of Duocel aluminum foam core sandwich panels using the ﬁnite element package ABAQUS, Version 6.11.11 It should be noted that usually the latest developments in the ﬁeld of foam plasticity constitutive modelling are promptly included in the ABAQUS commerical software.

sec.title: Theoretical approach
sec.p: In order to describe the damping response of sandwich composite beams, a two-dimensional (2D) analytical model was proposed based on the laminated plate theory together with the energy dissipation concept.12–14 The problem of local bending effects in sandwich panels and beams has been treated by many authors.6,15–17 Only the principal bending moment Mx is applied along the x-direction, the other moments being zero:18 My=Mxy=0 (1) where the Dij -1 coefficients are the ﬂexural compliance matrix components, derived as the elements of the inverse matrix Dij expressed in the beam axes. The curvature κx is due to bending along the x-direction, the curvature κy is due to the poisson coupling and the curvature κxy results from the bending–twisting coupling. According to the classical laminate theory, the strain ﬁeld in the (x,y) directions of the beam can be expressed as functions of the curvatures. Next the stress ﬁeld is derived. As in the preceding analysis, the stresses σyy and σxy are neglected and only the stress σxx is considered, which leads to (2) where z is the distance referenced to the mid-plane of laminates. The relations between Qij and the basic engineering constants are described as: (3) where the elements Qij ' are the reduced stifness constants expressed in the (x,y) directions, which are related to Qij(i, j = 1,2,6), as follows: (4) (5) (6) (7) (8)

Theta defines as the fibre orientation and the stiffness constants Dij of the beam are related to the reduced stiffness constants Qij ' of the material by the expression:19,20 (9) and the compliance components Dij -1 are given by: (10)
Then, using the stress transformations, the stresses in the material directions are given by: (11) (12) (13)

The strains in the material directions can be expressed as functions of the strains in the beam directions considering the strain transformations.20,21 Because ɛyy is much smaller than ɛxx and γxy, the strains in the material directions are given by: (14)
The strain energy dissipation can be divided into three parts related to in-plane stresses such as σx, σy and σxy in the ﬁbre coordinate (15) (16) (17) (18)

In more detail, they are rewritten as: (19) (20) (21) where a is the length of beam, h is the thickness of beam, t is the thickness of core, ηL is the axial damping loss factor,22 ηT is the basic transverse damping loss factor, ηLT is the basic in-plane shear damping loss factor, Mx=px is the principal bending moment in the cantilever beam,23 I=h3/12 is the normalized moment of inertia, D11 f -1 is the compliance components of Duocel aluminum foam core,10 D16 c -1 is the compliance components of composite layer. ηi is the modal loss factors, related to the speciﬁc damping coefficient by the relation ϕi=2πηi. The total strain energy of the beam can be expressed as:21 (22)
Then, the speciﬁc damping capacity Ψ is given by: (23)

sec.title: Finite element analysis
sec.p:
It is known that the plastic response of cellular materials (foams) differs signiﬁcantly from that of the fully dense materials owing to compaction of foams. The purpose of the ﬁnite element analysis was to predict the damping behaviour of foam core sandwich composite beams.22–25 The core was sandwiched between two face sheet. Therefore, we decided to model the damping behaviour of Duocel aluminum foam core sandwich panels using the ABAQUS commercial software, Version 6.11. Four-nodded axisymmetric (CAX4R) ﬁnite elements were used to discrete the sandwich core and the composite face sheets.26,27 The input data for this option are shown in Table 1.28,29 Before doing further calculations, a mesh sensitivity study with respect to the number of elements and the bias ratio was performed to ensure that the ﬁnite element mesh was ﬁne enough to give satisfactory results. Each contact interaction can refer to a contact property that specifies a model for the interaction between the contacting surfaces. ABAQUS provides more than one approach for defining contact. The contact behaviour was defined using the TANGENTIAL BEHAVIOR option. All degrees of freedom of the indentor were constrained, except the vertical translation. The indentor was modelled as a rigid sphere using a rigid body option in the ABAQUS program.30,31 All degrees of freedom at the right boundary of the sandwich specimen were constrained. Figure 1 displays the adopted ﬁnite element model (mesh and boundary conditions). The elastic part of the response of the core was deﬁned by the ELASTIC option.32–34 The plastic part of the response of the core material was modelled using the POROUS METAL PLASTICITY option in the ABAQUS commerical software. Figure 1.
Two-dimensional ﬁnite element meshing models of aluminum foam core sandwich composite beams. Table 1.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Damping parameters were ﬁrst measured in the case of unidirectional beams of glass ﬁbre composites as function of ﬁbre orientation.12,19,24,35 If a laminate deforms in an undesirable way during loading or curing (e.g. warps), it may not be able to fulﬁll its design requirements despite desirable energy dissipation characteristics. Figure 2 shows the evolution of the vertical displacement ﬁeld. It is clear that the indentation effects are localized in the vicinity of the indentor. Figure 3 depicts the distribution of the Von Mises stress according to the ﬁnite element analysis. The compressive stress has a maximum in the zone underneath the indentor. Figure 4 shows the vertical strain ɛ22 obtained in the finite element analysis. The ﬁeld has a strong highly deformed (compressed) zone that is localized under the indentor. Next, the modal responses of the structure were derived by ﬁnite element analysis. Figure 5 shows the shapes of the ﬁrst six modes deduced from ﬁnite element analysis. Mode 1 is a longitudinal bending mode, modes 2 and 3 are twisting modes. The other modes combine these different effects (Figure 5). This analysis considers the modal loss factors and the analysis was nonlinear. Mode 1 leads to a resonance peak at 719.16 Hz. Modes 2 and 3 combine to yield two resonance peaks at frequencies of 2017.6 Hz and 3819.8 Hz. Mode 4 leads to a resonance peak at 4585.6 Hz, and mode 6 to a resonance peak about 5277.3 Hz. The amplitudes of the peaks are slightly decreased in the case of the structure constituted of the sandwich material. However, the higher damping is obtained in the case of the structure constituted of the aluminum foam core sandwich composite beams. A signiﬁcantly higher damping could be obtained using a thicker layer. The effective laminate damping loss factors determined by the theoretical approach and the numerical simulations was performed using the ABAQUS ﬁnite element computer code are plotted in Figures 6 to 9 for the four laminates, [0∘\90∘\±θ∘]2s, [45∘\(θ+90)∘\±θ∘]2s, [(θ+90)∘\-θ∘\(θ-45)∘\θ∘]2s and [±θ∘]2sbeams. Figure 6 shows that in the stacking sequences [0∘\90∘\±θ∘]2s for θ=40∘, damping is maximum value predictions for the [45∘\(θ+90)∘\±θ∘]2s laminate, the damping increases to a maximum value at −13° (Figure 7) predictions for the [(θ+90)∘\-θ∘\(θ-45)∘\θ∘]2s laminate, the damping increases to a maximum value at 110° (Figure 8). In this study, we observed that the stacking sequences [±θ∘]2s has maximum damping when θ=75∘ (Figure 9). It is necessary to recognize that the value of the specific damping capacity may not be the only laminate property of interest. Also when compared to the theoretical models, the present models demonstrate good agreement with the FEM data. Next, the inﬂuence of the beam thickness was studied and the results obtained show that in the stacking sequences [±θ∘]2s for a/t≈5, damping is maximum value (Figure 10). The variations of the damping loss factor with respect to fibre orientation are shown in Figures 6 to 9. Damping variations as function of fibre orientation and length/thickness are shown in Figures 10 to 13. The damping–frequency curve, deduced from the ﬁnite element modelling, is shown in Figure 14. For a given ﬁbre orientation, it is observed that damping increases when the frequency is increased (Figure 14). Comparison between the maximum values of loss factor η evaluated by the different analyses is shown in Table 2. Comparison between the values of length/thickness (a/t) in the maximum value of damping is shown in Table 3. Figure 2.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
Fibre angles in composites and length to thickness ratio of beam are of the most effective factors on the damping. Here the energy method is used to calculate damping. Finite element analysis allows us to derive the different strain energies stored in the material directions of the constituents of composite materials, and next, the energy dissipated by damping in the materials and the composite structure can be obtained as a function of the strain energies and the damping coefficients associated with the different energies stored in the material directions. The damping loss factor appears to increase with increasing thickness owing to the effect of transverse shear and decrease with increasing length. Determination of an optimized length and thickness for a structure of which the structural damping is at a maximum is very important for designing a structure with good dynamic performance. Beam damping depends on the vibration modes and the damping evaluation was related with the mode shapes of the beam vibration. The damping characteristics of the composite materials and of the constituents can be deduced by applying modelling to the vibrations of beams. So it can be obtained: the loss factors in the material directions of the different layers of laminated materials, the damping characteristics of the layers, as well as the ones of the foam cores. In the present work, the modelling of the damping distribution in vibrating composite structures is established with the lowest residual errors. The fitted results of the measured values indicate the following:
There is an existence of generalized linear relationships between the loss factors and the natural frequencies of aluminum foam core sandwich composite beams and can be found at any selected range of frequency spectrum.
The stacking sequences [±θ∘]2s has maximum damping compared with the other stacking sequences.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
